p.s: The text Language learning in the UK: 'can't, won't, don't' written by John Worne deals with the importance of learning foreign languages in the UK.

In the first line the author refers to his headline 'can't, won't, don't', he does that to begin his text with a statement and shows that these words are important because they show the view in the UK on learning a foreign language at this point.

After that the author uses a bad conotatedconnotated word sadly(l. 4) with that word he shows that he is not satisfied with the situation in which the UK is at the momemoment and it also makes clear that he thinks something has to change.

In the following he makes use of an antithesis while there is some progress - languages are now on the menu in more primary schools - there's a long haul ahead(ll. 6-7) for the reader it is clear now that the author is happy about this change but has the opinion that this change is way totoo less to really change something and it is not really a big in win in that topic.
It is a good thing which is done but can notcannot erase the whole language problem.

After that he focuses on statistics about fewer people taking language A-Levels More than 10,000 fewer language A-Level exams were taken last year than at the end of the 1990s he does that to show that the trend is really goign down and that he is not just a crazy man who thinks there is a problem, with this statistic he can prove that there is a problem and something has to be done.

He now gives point from the other side which he tiresly weakens Everyone speaks English in the world of business (they don't), your iPhone will now translate road signs for you (but you may crash or choke on the roaming data charges) (ll. 12-14) he does that to show that it is no way to rely on your phone or to think that everybody could speak English because it is clear that not everybody can.
The only possible and right way for yourself is to learn the language and then to speak it and to make use of it.

Furthermore he is ironical in that sentence Perfectly intelligent people will tell you(l. 12) it shows that he is not persuaded by their points and views in addition to that he has the opinion that their points and unclever even dumb.
Another stilisticstylistic device he usese is to use an informal word cobblers(l. 15).
It is here he used to lead the readersreader's attention to the said things and to show how false the ideas of the perfectly intelligent people are.
In the middle of the text he makes a clear statement Language learning is vital for the UK's future prosperity and global standing(l. 16).
thisThis is the main statement and is used in the middle of his text to show the importance of learning foreign languages for the UK itself.
He uses the strong verb vital this shows that there is no other way than learning foreign languages to help the UK.

After that the author makes use of a list trade, prosperity, cultural exports, diplomacy and national security(ll. 17-18) this device makes clear what is connected with learning foreign languages and being able to use them.

In the next part of the text the author focuses on the next statistic in this case it is a survey The most recent CBI / Pearson Education and skills survey showed almost two-thirds of UK businessbusinesses need foreign language skills(ll. 19-20) with that he underlines his whole point to learn foreign languages with an officla statistic which creates the opinion from the reader that the author is right.

He knownow uses positivpositively connotated words the only really good piece of news is forward-thinking universities are offering students the chance to study a language alongside another degree subject(ll. 24-25).
He wants the reader to understand that this is a good way to go and wants to persuade them with the use of this device.
At the end of his text the author appeals to other parents in the UK.

soSo, parents of the UKand I'm one, what it is going to take is a cultural shift in homes up and down the land.(ll. 32-34) He wants to persuade parents to help their children learning foreign languages and make it easier for them in their later lifeslives.
To conclude the author has the opinion that foreign languages need to be taught everywhere in the UK because it is not only important for you it is important for the whole country.
